systems</topcClas>         <topcClas>Income, property and investment - Economics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The aim of this survey was to analyse and compare the income and expenditure patterns of households containing a disabled adult with other households.  To provide a comparative measure of the extra costs of disability to complement the subjective measures used in the OPCS Survey of Disabled Adults in Private Households  (SN:2577, GN:33214).</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br> Disability; income; expenditure; benefit receipt; employment; costs of disability; standard of living; disability aids.<br> Disabled adult respondents to the continuous Family Expenditure Survey (FES) between July 1986 and June 1987 were given an additional interview after participation in the FES. Detailed information on their disability was collected, to analyse in conjunction with information on income and expenditure from the main FES.<br> Measurement Scales Used<br> Disability Severity Scales: disability was defined and measured using the severity scale developed in the OPCS Surveys of Disability in Great Britain (GN:33214).</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1986-07-01T00:00:00Z">July 1986</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="1987-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 1987</timePrd>         <collDate event="start" date="1986-07-01T00:00:00Z">July 1986</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="1987-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 1987</collDate>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Standard Statistical Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Disabled people</universe>         <universe>Disabled adults (aged 16 and over) and their households in Great Britain.</universe>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Follow-up to cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Office of Population Censuses and Surveys.
